questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the local urgent care with a right facial droop and ear pain. The symptoms started three days ago and have been insidious. Review of systems is significant for persistent dizziness and nausea. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection. She declined antiretroviral therapy at the time of diagnosis  two years ago. She went camping in Massachusetts with her family three months ago. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.5°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows the right eyelid drooping with loss of the nasolabial fold on the right side. Multiple vesicles are seen in the right auditory canal and the auricle, with sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and on the auricle most likely has Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus), a major otologic complication varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection.

The etiology is the reactivation of latent VZV in the geniculate ganglion. Following primary VZV infection (chickenpox), the virus migrates via sensory nerves to the cranial nerves and ganglia, where it lies dormant for years. Risk factors for reactivation include immunocompromised states like recent chemoradiotherapy, pregnancy, transplant patients, and HIV infection with low CD4 count (as in this patient). The classic triad is ipsilateral facial paralysis (due to involvement of CN VII), ear pain, and vesicular lesions in the auditory canal or on the auricle. Other findings include altered taste perception, tongue lesions, and decreased lacrimation. The involvement of CN VIII can cause hearing abnormalities (sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, hyperacusis) and vertigo.

The treatment of choice is the guanosine analog valacyclovir with prednisone. Treatment should be initiated as soon as possible, as treatment is associated with decreased risk of postherpetic neuralgia and spread of infection.

Option Analysis

❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is considered in patients with early disseminated Lyme disease with neurologic symptoms. Although this patient traveled to a Lyme-endemic area three months ago, the development of a vesicular rash and CN VIII symptoms (vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss) makes herpes zoster a more likely diagnosis.
✅ Valacyclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Foscarnet:
Incorrect: Foscarnet is a viral DNA polymerase inhibitor used for acyclovir-resistant HSV infections and as an alternative to ganciclovir for the prophylaxis and treatment of CMV infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is not first-line in this patient’s case.
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Incorrect: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) therapy can be considered in patients with neuroinvasive West Nile virus infection, which presents with signs and symptoms of meningoencephalitis (headache, photophobia, confusion). Development of a vesicular rash would be atypical.
❌ Hydration and supportive therapy:
Incorrect: Hydration and supportive therapy are considered in viral infections with no specific treatment, like Zika virus which presents with maculopapular rash, arthralgia and conjunctivitis after recent travel to endemic areas (e.g., Africa, Southeast Asia, the Pacific Islands, the Americas, and the Caribbean).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with facial drooping. The patient reports difficulty drinking coffee earlier this morning, along with drooling of saliva from the right side of his mouth. He had no symptoms when he went to bed last night. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. He inconsistently takes amlodipine and metformin. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 161/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows loss of the nasolabial fold and drooping from the lips on the right side with an asymmetric smile. The patient can frown, elevate the eyebrows and close his eyes. The rest of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. The lesion most likely occurred at which of the following levels?
questions.solution:
This patient with paralysis of the lower right side of the face most likely has an upper motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve (CN VII). Common causes include stroke, multiple sclerosis, subdural hemorrhage, and intracranial neoplasia. Of the choices listed, the cerebral cortex is the region where a UMN lesion can demonstrate such findings.

The motor pathway for the facial nerve starts from the motor cortex, where its upper motor neuron (UMN) travels downwards through the internal capsule to reach the facial motor nucleus in the lateral pons. This nucleus has a dorsal and ventral part. The former innervates muscles of the upper face and lacrimation, while the latter innervates muscles of the lower face and salivation. The dorsal region receives innervation from the UMN of both hemispheres. The ventral region receives innervation only from the UMN of the opposite hemisphere. That is why unilateral UMN lesions only affect the lower part of the face on the contralateral side.

The UMN fibers cross over before they synapse with LMN, which then travel ipsilaterally, supplying the same side of the face. Therefore, an LMN lesion affects the upper and lower side of the face ipsilaterally.









Option Analysis

✅ Cerebral cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Facial nucleus in the pons:
Incorrect: The axons of UMN enter the facial nucleus, where they synapse with LMN. Lesions in the pons usually involve LMN and result in paralysis of all of the facial muscles on the ipsilateral side (including those of the upper face).
❌ Cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: A facial nerve lesion at the cerebellopontine angle would be an LMN lesion that presents as ipsilateral paralysis of the upper and lower facial muscles.
❌ Parotid gland:
Incorrect: A lesion of the facial nerve while it travels through the parotid gland would be an LMN lesion that presents as ipsilateral paralysis of the upper and lower facial muscles.
❌ Internal acoustic meatus:
Incorrect: A facial nerve lesion at the level of the internal acoustic meatus would be an LMN lesion that presents as ipsilateral paralysis of the upper and lower facial muscles.

questions.text: A 65-year-old person is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right-sided weakness. They were eating dinner when, suddenly, they could not lift their fork. Upon standing up, the patient’s right side gave away, and they fell onto the carpet. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which the patient takes amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Physical examination shows deviation of the eyes to the left side. Motor strength is 0/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient’s ocular findings?

choices.text: Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
Lesion involving the right frontal eye field
Lesion involving the left frontal eye field
Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)
Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with right-sided hemiplegia and deviation of the eyes to the left. They likely have a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory stroke involving the left frontal eye field.  

The frontal eye field refers to an area of the frontal lobe involved in visual field perception and voluntary eye movements. It plays a crucial role in conjugate horizontal gaze and saccades (fast eye movements).  

In order to look to the right, the left frontal eye field synapses to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) via the superior colliculus. The efferent pathway from the PPRF passes to the right lateral rectus motor neurons (via the CN VI nucleus), resulting in abduction of the right eye. Excitatory signals are also sent to the contralateral medial rectus motor neurons (CN III) via the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), resulting in adduction of the contralateral (left) eye.  

Horizontal gaze palsy is typically caused by either a contralateral frontal eye field lesion or an ipsilateral PPRF lesion.   

The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere. Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery (MCA) can lead to lesions that also involve the frontal eye field. Clinically, the eyes will deviate towards the side of the lesion (left-sided MCA stroke with right-sided hemiplegia means that eyes will be deviated to the left). In contrast, a lesion involving the PPRF results in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF):
Incorrect: A lesion affecting the unilateral MLF impairs adduction of the ipsilateral medial rectus, resulting in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) – a conjugate horizontal gaze palsy.
❌ Lesion involving the right frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Preferential gaze is controlled by the contralateral frontal eye field. This patient presents with an inability to gaze to the right, which is consistent with a lesion in her left frontal eye field.
✅ Lesion involving the left frontal eye field:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: A lesion involving the PPRF results in an ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). A lesion in this area does not explain the patient’s right-sided motor deficits.
❌ Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: Lesions involving the PPRF result in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). This patient has left-sided eye deviation (rather than the inability to look left), and a lesion in this area would not explain their right-sided motor deficits.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of facial weakness. Earlier in the morning, she had trouble drinking coffee as it was drooling from the right side of her face. Her partner mentioned that her face was drooping, and she noticed that she could not move her mouth or eyebrows on that side. She has not had hearing loss, ringing sensation in the ears, or difficulty walking. She underwent a right superficial parotidectomy for the resection of a pleomorphic adenoma in the parotid gland two days ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows asymmetry of the face with smiling. There is also loss of the right nasolabial fold, with drooping of the eyelids and lips on the right side. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve

questions.solution:
This patient has new-onset right-sided facial weakness causing drooling from the right side of the face, facial droop, asymmetric smile, and inability to move the eyebrow after recent surgery involving the parotid gland. She likely suffered intraoperative facial nerve injury causing ipsilateral facial muscle paralysis.

During its extracranial course, the motor component of the facial nerve enters the parotid gland, where it forms the parotid plexus. This plexus then divides into the terminal branches to innervate the facial muscles. Injury to this area (e.g., secondary to trauma, iatrogenic, etc.) can lead to ipsilateral paralysis of the facial muscles. Since the nerves to the stapedius and chorda tympani branch proximal to this area, the patient does not experience hyperacusis or abnormalities in taste.

Patients with paralysis need to keep the eye lubricated (with artificial tears) and closed while sleeping (with a taping of the eye) to prevent corneal trauma and desiccation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tick-borne illness:
Incorrect: Early disseminated Lyme disease can involve CN VII, leading to facial nerve palsy. However, it is usually accompanied by a macular rash, arthralgia, and aseptic meningitis. Considering the recent surgery, the temporal association of symptoms makes it a more likely cause.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face due to dual UMN control of the upper face, thereby sparing it. This patient has paralysis of upper facial muscles, making UMN lesion less likely.
❌ Reactivation of a dormant virus:
Incorrect: The major complication of reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. This patient does not have otalgia, and physical examination of the auricle and auditory canal is unremarkable.
✅ Recent surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tumor at the cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: Even though a tumor at a cerebellopontine angle (e.g. schwannoma) can sometimes involve facial nerve, it is usually preceded by the symptoms of CN VIII impingement (i.e., tinnitus, ataxia, vertigo, or sensorineural hearing loss), none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery. He was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 27-year-old woman who had inconsistent prenatal care. The mother’s medical history includes generalized seizures managed with carbamazepine. She took routine prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy. The mother has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years, she does not use alcohol, and she used cocaine 1-2 times per month during the pregnancy.  Physical examination of the patient shows a newborn male in no acute distress. The patient moves the upper extremities freely but not the lower extremities. There is a red, fleshy, swelling present on the lower back. Stroking the skin around the anus does not produce a contraction of the anal sphincter. Which of the following interventions could have prevented this neonate’s abnormalities?

choices.text: Increasing the dose of prenatal vitamins

questions.solution:
This neonate is presenting with an abnormal lesion on the lower back, paraplegia, and loss of anal sphincter tone -- a presentation consistent with meningomyelocele. 

Open neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital anomalies that develop when the neural tube fails to close normally during the third and fourth weeks of gestation. NTDs may be open (e.g., myelomeningocele, meningocele, encephalocele, and anencephaly) or closed (e.g. spina bifida occulta).   Risk factors for developing closed or open neural tube defects include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Most isolated NTDs appear to be caused by folate deficiency, probably in combination with genetic or environmental risk factors. Folate deficiency may arise from inadequate oral intake, malabsorption, use of folic acid antagonists, or genetic causes of abnormal folate metabolism. Folic acid supplementation is recommended for all women during preconception and the first trimester periods; 0.4 mg daily of folic acid is recommended for all women, beginning before conception and continued through pregnancy. For women taking carbamazepine or valproate, or those with a prior infant with an NTD or with an NTD affecting either parent, a higher folic acid dose of 4 mg daily is recommended.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Cessation of cocaine use:
Incorrect: Cocaine is a potent vasoconstrictor, and therefore, it can cause fetal and placental injury leading to placental abruption, spontaneous abortion, prematurity, and fetal death. Neural tube defects, as seen in this patient, are not associated with cocaine use.  
❌ Smoking cessation:
Incorrect: Tobacco use negatively affects both maternal and fetal health and continues over into the postnatal period. Tobacco use is associated with neonatal death, reduction in birth weight, placental abruption, placenta previa, and preterm birth. It is also associated with specific congenital malformations such as cleft lip with gastroschisis, cardiac defects, digital anomalies, bilateral renal agenesis, and anal atresia but not neural tube defects.   
❌ Changing carbamazepine to valproate:
Incorrect: Both valproate and carbamazepine, as well as other folate antagonists (e.g., methotrexate), are associated with neural tube defects. Therefore, changing to valproate is unlikely to change the prognosis.   
✅ Increasing the dose of prenatal vitamins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a weight check. The patient was born at 37.5 weeks gestation by uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The mother did not know she was pregnant until she was 14 weeks gestation, and she did not receive adequate prenatal care. The patient passed meconium on day one of life but has not stooled since. Parents report she is bottle feeding well with good urine output. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is down 5% from birth weight. Physical examination demonstrates a well-appearing neonate in no acute distress. There is a small tuft of hair above the gluteal cleft as seen in the image below. Abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended, with normoactive bowel sounds. Rectal examination does not demonstrate evidence of imperforate anus but does show a diminished anal wink reflex. The patient is moving all extremities but has decreased tone in the lower extremities. Which of the following tests should be performed next?
 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This 5-day-old neonate presents with decreased stool output despite good oral intake and urine output. The patient passed meconium within 48 hours of delivery and has evidence of a sacral dimple and tuft of hair concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. When a spinal cord abnormality is suspected, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine should be performed to assess for tethered cord syndrome, myelomeningocele, or spinal cord tumor.

Newborn patients with constipation should be assessed regarding the timing of meconium passage. Newborns with delayed passage of meconium (> 48 hours from delivery) are more likely to suffer from an anatomic obstruction or intestinal obstruction. These patients should be assessed for the presence of an imperforate anus or intestinal obstruction. Patients with an obstruction will demonstrate evidence of dilated loops of bowel on radiographs. Patients with Hirschsprung disease will often have evidence of decreased or absent air in the distal segment of the intestines. Patients with meconium ileus will have evidence of a “bubbly appearance” in the distended intestinal loops.

Newborns that have difficulty stooling after delivery (though not necessarily in the first 48 hours after delivery) should be assessed for possible spinal cord disorder. This may present as a deep sacral dimple, sacral tuft of hair, absent anal wink, or decreased lower extremity reflexes. If there is concern for a spinal cord abnormality, a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine should be obtained to assess for the presence of meningomyelocele, spinal cord tumor, or tethered cord.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. A spinal cord abnormality is best evaluated by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine. An abdominal X-ray is unlikely to provide additional, useful diagnostic information. An abdominal X-ray is indicated when there is concern for intestinal obstruction. 
❌ Contrast enema:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. A spinal cord abnormality is best evaluated by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine. A contrast enema is indicated in newborns when there is concern for meconium ileus or Hirschsprung disease. 
❌ Ultrasound of the spine:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. Although an ultrasound of the spine is occasionally used when there is concern for a spinal cord abnormality, the sensitivity is suboptimal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is preferred. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine would best evaluate this patient’s anatomy, and an MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is unlikely to provide additional useful diagnostic information.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of chronic headaches. The headaches have gradually worsened in frequency, intensity, and severity despite trials of multiple migraine preventative medications. Head pain worsens with coughing, sneezing, and bending over. The patient reports difficulty swallowing for the past three months. There are no other medical problems and no regular medications aside from over-the-counter analgesics. There is no history of tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. There is no family history of similar symptoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears to be swaying with down-beating nystagmus. There is decreased sensation over the shoulders and arms. Strength and reflexes are normal. Gait is slightly wide based. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and cervical spine without contrast
Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of chronic cerebellar dysfunction, including headaches worsened by Valsalva maneuvers, dysphagia, and a cape-like distribution of sensory loss in the upper extremities. These findings raise concern for a structural cause, such as cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum, known as a Chiari malformation. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and cervical spine is the most appropriate test to confirm structural cerebellar lesions.        

Evaluating the timing and progression of symptoms, laterality, family history, suspicion for malignancy, and history of alcohol use can help narrow the differential diagnosis and guide further workup.       

Acute cerebellar dysfunction is often due to ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, infectious cerebellitis, or postinfectious cerebellar ataxia. In such cases, neuroimaging is essential. While computed tomography (CT) can rapidly identify hemorrhages, MRI provides greater detail and is generally preferred.       

In patients with subacute or chronic cerebellar symptoms, MRI is often diagnostic for chiari type I malformations, multiple system atrophy (cerebellar type), and alcoholic cerebellar degeneration. Genetic testing for trinucleotide repeat expansions can confirm hereditary ataxias such as Friedreich ataxia and various forms of spinocerebellar ataxia. In cases of suspected paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, serum and cerebrospinal fluid analysis may detect specific antineuronal autoantibodies associated with underlying malignancy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and cervical spine without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: CT is less sensitive for posterior fossa abnormalities and does not provide adequate visualization of the brainstem or cerebellar tonsils. MRI is preferred for evaluating chronic cerebellar symptoms or structural causes of increased intracranial pressure. 
❌ GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion analysis of the frataxin gene :
Incorrect: Individuals with hereditary ataxias, like Friedreich ataxia, can also experience symptoms of chronic cerebellar dysfunction. However, this patient’s accompanying headache with symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure suggests a structural etiology. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) paraneoplastic panel:
Incorrect: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration typically presents with subacute cerebellar ataxia and occurs in the setting of malignancy. Neuroimaging is indicated first in patients with signs of brainstem or cerebellar compression, and lumbar puncture should be avoided until structural lesions are excluded. 
❌ CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion analysis of the ataxin-3 gene :
Incorrect: Individuals with hereditary ataxias, like spinocerebellar ataxia, can experience symptoms of chronic cerebellar dysfunction; however, this patient’s accompanying headache with symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure suggests a structural etiology.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute urinary retention and low back pain. The patient was performing dead-lifts at the gym when he felt the weight was too heavy and suddenly fell backwards to the floor. He has since had right low back and flank pain. The patient went home and took several analgesics but became increasingly concerned when he was unable to urinate. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 167/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 99/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable. Abdominal exam is significant for suprapubic fullness. The patient has no step offs or deformities overlying the lumbar spine. The patient is unable to ambulate due to pain and weakness in the legs. Bladder scan reveals >1L.  Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute urinary retention in the setting of severe back pain and injury, and lower extremity weakness which is concerning for cauda equina syndrome. Decreased anal sphincter tone, lower extremity weakness, and saddle anesthesia (numbness around the groin and buttocks) can be signs and symptoms of cauda equina syndrome.

Urinary retention refers to the inability to voluntarily empty the urinary bladder. It can be acute or chronic, and range from partial to complete urinary retention. Urinary retention has multiple causes including spinal cord compression or injury, medication side effects, urethral obstruction, and urinary tract infections.

Patients who present with urinary retention should be assessed for chronicity of symptoms followed by a detailed history and assessment for neurological red flags such as lower extremity weakness and decreased anal sphincter tone that would require immediate evaluation and intervention. Patients should be asked about risk factors for urinary retention such as medications (e.g. anticholinergic agents, antipsychotics, opioids), history of anatomic obstruction such as benign prostatic hyperplasia, or elements that suggest urinary tract infection (e.g. dysuria). Typical physical examination findings associated with urinary retention include suprapubic fullness and tenderness.

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased anal sphincter tone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enlarged prostate:
Incorrect: While BPH is a common cause of acute urinary retention, in this patient with acute low back pain, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness, cauda equina syndrome is more likely.  
❌ Miosis:
Incorrect:  Miosis, is a common ocular finding that occurs with opiate use which can lead to urinary retention. In this patient with acute low back injury, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness, cauda equina syndrome is more likely.  
❌ Hematuria:
Incorrect: Hematuria can occur in patients with underlying urinary tract infection or in patients with bladder masses, but these causes of urinary retention would be less likely than cauda equina syndrome in this patient with acute low back injury and urinary retention.  
❌ Frequent use of diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Anticholinergic agents such as diphenhydramine can result in acute urinary retention; however, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found down outside in a nearby park next to a stone wall. EMS reports that a bystander called after the patient was unable to be aroused. He was given a one-time dose of naloxone intranasally in the field without significant improvement. The patient's past medical history is unknown, but bystanders say he usually sleeps in the park. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate 50/min, blood pressure 162/42 mmHg, respiratory rate 8/min and irregular, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation 93% on room air. The patient is moaning with slurred speech. He has a large hematoma on the right side of his head and significant ecchymoses on the right shoulder, elbow, and hip. He is moving all extremities spontaneously. Pupillary examination reveals normal-sized pupils bilaterally that are equal, reactive, and oval-shaped, Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals irregular respirations, but no murmurs are present. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdominal exam is within normal limits. Point-of-care blood glucose is within normal limits. An arterial blood gas is drawn and shows a pH 7.27 and a pCO<sub>2</sub> 52. Which of the following tests will most likely confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after being found down and is found to have a hematoma on the right side of the head and ecchymoses on the right side of the body. He has respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis, irregular breathing, bradycardia, and widened pulse pressure (Cushing Triad). These findings are consistent with Cushing triad (bradycardia, Kussmaul respirations, and a widened pulse pressure) along with the finding of bilateral papilledema, are indicative of elevated intracranial pressure. Given the evidence of increased intracranial pressure and signs of head trauma, a computed tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast should be performed to evaluate for and intracranial processes such as traumatic intracranial hemorrhage.

Many conditions can cause respiratory acidosis, including central nervous system (CNS), neuromuscular, obstructive, and pulmonary parenchymal etiologies. Determining a differential diagnosis and subsequent diagnostic workup for patients with respiratory acidosis should be tailored to the underlying history and physical examination findings. For example, for patients with a likely neurological process, the physical exam may reveal decreased respiratory rate, altered mental status, or focal neurological deficits. These patients should undergo further evaluation with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or CT and should be screened for substance intoxication/overdose. Historical and physical examination findings and diagnostic tests associated with the different causes of respiratory acidosis are summarized in the chart above.        

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography (CT) brain without contrast :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chest X-ray:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of Cushing triad and bilateral papillary edema and head trauma, making an intracranial process most likely.  
❌ Serum ethanol level :
Incorrect: Alcohol Intoxication/overdose should be considered in the differential for a patient with undifferentiated respiratory acidosis; however, this patient has evidence of Cushing triad, bilateral papilledema, and head trauma, making an intracranial process most likely. 
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: Intoxication with recreational substances should be considered in the differential for a patient with undifferentiated respiratory acidosis; however, this patient has evidence of the Cushing triad, papilledema, and head trauma, making an intracranial process most likely. Furthermore, the patient was given naloxone without significant improvement, making acute opiate overdose less likely.  
❌ Ammonia level  :
Incorrect: Hyperammonemia can result in altered mental status and subsequent respiratory acidosis; however, this patient has no findings consistent with end-stage liver disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with two days of acute lower back pain. He describes the pain as a constant, dull ache that has progressively worsened, and now radiates to both legs. The pain intensifies with movement and is unrelieved by over-the-counter pain medications. He denies any recent trauma or overexertion. He has also had 2-3 episodes of urinary incontinence and one episode of bowel incontinence over the past 24 hours. The patient is under active treatment for recently diagnosed prostate cancer. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mmHg. The patient appears uncomfortable and has difficulty standing up straight. There is localized tenderness over the lumbar spine but no obvious deformity. Neurological examination reveals 5/5 strength in the bilateral upper and lower extremities and mild sensory loss in the perineum. There is decreased rectal tone on digital rectal examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine
Oxycodone for 1 week with outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute low back pain associated with red flag symptoms, including urinary and bowel incontinence, sensory loss in the perineum, and decreased rectal tone. These findings raise concern for cauda equina syndrome, which is a medical emergency that can result from spinal cord compression, in this case likely due to metastatic disease from prostate cancer. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine should be performed urgently to confirm the condition and guide management.

Assessment of patients with back pain should begin with a focused history and physical examination to differentiate between benign and serious causes. Red flag symptoms, such as neurological deficits, incontinence, or history of cancer necessitate immediate imaging studies, typically MRI, to rule out serious underlying conditions such as cauda equina syndrome or metastatic disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and referral to physical therapy :
Incorrect: While NSAIDs and physical therapy can be part of the management for mechanical back pain, they are inappropriate in this case due to the presence of red flag symptoms indicating potential spinal cord compression, which requires urgent evaluation and treatment.    
❌ Muscle relaxants and 24-hour bed rest:
Incorrect: Muscle relaxants may help alleviate symptoms in benign causes of back pain (e.g., muscle spasm) but are not suitable for addressing the likely serious underlying condition of cauda equina syndrome suggested by this patient's symptoms. Bed rest is not recommended in the management of most lower back pain. 
❌ Lumbar spine X-ray:
Incorrect: A lumbar spine X-ray can detect bony abnormalities but lacks the detailed imaging needed to evaluate soft tissue and neural structures, making it insufficient for diagnosing conditions like spinal cord compression.  
❌ Oxycodone for 1 week with outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: Prescribing oxycodone may provide temporary pain relief but does not address the urgent need to diagnose and treat this patient’s likely spinal cord compression, which could result in irreversible neurological damage if not promptly managed.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is evaluated at a well child visit. The parents are concerned because the child is cruising but not yet walking. A friend's daughter began walking around 12 months of age. The patient was born at 29 weeks’ gestation with a birth weight of 1,350 grams. The pregnancy was complicated by eclampsia requiring emergency cesarean delivery. The infant was in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) and discharged at 3 months of age. The hospital course was complicated by respiratory distress syndrome, grade III intraventricular hemorrhage without calcifications, and anemia that required multiple transfusions. Other developmental milestones are appropriate for age. The infant passed a repeat hearing screen at 12 months. Follow-up with ophthalmology shows no concerns. Weight, height, and head circumference are at the 20<sup>th</sup> percentile for age on the World Health Organization growth curve. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 83/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The anterior fontanelle is closed. Physical exam is notable for hypertonia, spastic lower extremities, and hyperreflexia but is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following diagnostic measures would best help to determine the underlying cause of this patient’s developmental delay?

choices.text: Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (MCHAT) survey
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
This infant was born at 29 weeks’ gestation and has a history of a grade III intraventricular hemorrhage. At 18 months old, the patient is not walking and has hypertonia, spastic lower extremities, and hyperreflexia – findings consistent with cerebral palsy. This is likely secondary to periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) following intraventricular hemorrhage, which can be further evaluated by MRI of the brain.

Premature infants are at increased risk of delays in cognitive, motor, language, and social development, which are often associated with comorbid conditions. A history of perinatal infections, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, intraventricular hemorrhage, fetal growth restriction, or brain injury may be revealed. Depending on the underlying pathology, physical exam findings can include macro- or microcephaly and abnormal muscle tone, such as hypotonia or spasticity. If neurodevelopmental impairment is suspected, a full developmental assessment should be performed.

Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is an ischemic brain injury causing cavitation and cyst formation in the periventricular white matter. The rate of PVL is inversely related to gestational age and birth weight. It is a common cause of cerebral palsy in preterm infants. Depending on the severity, PVL can be associated with motor and cognitive impairments, seizures, and visual disturbances. Risk factors include hypoxemia, hypotension, and intraventricular hemorrhage. Physical exam may reveal an uncoordinated suck-swallow in neonates, hypertonia, spasticity, and motor delays. For those with risk factors, including a gestational age of 30 weeks or less, cranial ultrasound screening can detect PVL. MRI is needed once the anterior fontanelle closes.
 
Cranial ultrasound shows bilateral periventricular white matter cysts adjacent to the frontal horns. Reproduced from: StatdxStatdx   

Option Analysis

❌ Congenital cytomegalovirus (cCMV) serologies:
Incorrect: While cerebral palsy can be a late complication of cCMV, it is typically accompanied by other findings such as a history of being small for gestational age, microcephaly, hearing loss, visual impairment, and intracranial calcifications, none of which are present in this patient. This developmental delay in this case is more likely due to cerebral palsy secondary to the intraventricular hemorrhage and resulting periventricular leukomalacia (PVL). MRI of the head would help evaluate for white matter injury.
❌ Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (MCHAT) survey:
Incorrect: Children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) usually experience developmental delays in one or more areas, including social and emotional development. The MCHAT is used to evaluate for ASD. However, this patient’s delay appears to be primarily motor-related and likely due to cerebral palsy, which is associated with a history of intraventricular hemorrhage. MRI of the brain would be more useful for assessing white matter injury.
❌ Physical therapy (PT) evaluation:
Incorrect: While PT is beneficial for this patient, the best next step to evaluate the underlying cause of this patient’s motor delay is MRI of the brain. This will help assess for periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) or other white matter injuries that may be contributing to the motor issues, rather than just providing therapy.
❌ Genetic testing for muscular dystrophy:
Incorrect: Muscular dystrophies typically present with calf muscle hypertrophy and weakness in the proximal muscles of the lower extremities, which are not present in this patient. This patient’s motor delays are more likely explained by cerebral palsy secondary to intraventricular hemorrhage. MRI of the brain would better assess for white matter injury.
✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A baby boy is born at 41 weeks of gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Delivery was complicated by prolonged labor requiring forceps. Apgars were 6 and 9. On initial evaluation, the infant is 4150 grams. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 162/min, respirations are 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The infant is crying vigorously, and the eyes remain shut. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is a palpable concave depression over the right parietal region. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head

questions.solution:
This newborn was born post-dates and is large for gestational age. The delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and the use of forceps. There is a depressed concave area over the right parietal region consistent with a depressed skull fracture. Neonates with depressed skull fractures often have associated intracranial hemorrhage; as such, they should be evaluated with computed tomography (CT) of the head.         

Newborn deliveries can result in head, nerve, skeletal, and soft tissue injuries; many of these injuries can be diagnosed clinically and do not require further evaluation. A cephalohematoma is a benign bleed under the scalp that typically resolves on its own. No imaging is needed. If there is concern for skull fracture or hemorrhage, a CT of the head is recommended. Occasionally, a head ultrasound is obtained to evaluate for intraventricular hemorrhage.        

Skeletal injuries, such as clavicle or long bone fractures, can be diagnosed with radiographs. Diagnosis of nerve palsies and soft tissue injuries can often be made clinically as long as there is no concern for underlying fracture.   

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography (CT) of the head:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Skull radiographs:
Incorrect: While radiographs evaluate bone, computed tomography (CT) of the head is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate a skull fracture since there can be an associated intracranial hemorrhage.  
❌ Cranial ultrasound:
Incorrect: Cranial ultrasound is often used to screen for intraventricular hemorrhage in premature infants. This patient has evidence of a depressed skull fracture for which computed tomography (CT) of the head is recommended. 
❌ No further imaging is required:
Incorrect: This patient has physical examination findings consistent with a depressed skull fracture. Because of the association with intracranial hemorrhage, a head CT should be performed. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head:
Incorrect: MRI is best for soft tissue injuries. Computed tomography (CT) of the head is the preferred option to evaluate for a skull fracture and associated intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling from a tree. The child landed on his back and briefly lost consciousness but is now awake and alert. There is no past medical history and no medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 104/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary survey is unremarkable. During the secondary survey, the child reports a headache and neck pain. Examination reveals midline cervical spine tenderness and mild bruising across the upper chest. The musculoskeletal examination is normal, with full range of motion and no swelling, tenderness, or deformities in any extremity. The abdomen is nontender, and distal pulses are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to evaluate this patient’s injuries?

choices.text: Cervical spine X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the head
Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) examination
X-rays of upper and lower extremities
Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old patient has clinical signs of head trauma (brief loss of consciousness, headache) and cervical spine trauma (midline cervical tenderness), both of which warrant immediate imaging. A non-contrast head CT is indicated to evaluate for intracranial hemorrhage or other brain injury. Cervical spine X-rays are appropriate to quickly assess for vertebral fracture, dislocation, or spinal cord injury, even if further imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is ultimately needed.

The diagnostic evaluation of a pediatric trauma patient follows stabilization during the primary survey and is guided by findings from the secondary survey. Head CT is warranted when there is loss of consciousness, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, or signs of skull fracture (e.g., skull irregularity, facial lacerations) or ocular injury (e.g., displacement of the globe, enophthalmos). Midline cervical tenderness or neurologic symptoms raise concern for cervical spine injury, which is initially assessed with cervical spine X-ray or, in some settings, CT. Thoracic trauma, suggested by chest pain, bruising, or abnormal breath sounds, is evaluated with chest imaging. Pelvic or genitourinary injury is indicated by pelvic tenderness, hematuria, or urethral bleeding and may require pelvic X-ray or CT. Musculoskeletal trauma is identified by swelling, tenderness, or deformity and evaluated with targeted extremity X-rays.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pelvic X-ray:
Incorrect: There are no pelvic tenderness, bruising, or signs of genitourinary injury to suggest a pelvic fracture or indicate the need for imaging. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.
✅ Cervical spine X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the head:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) examination:
Incorrect: The FAST exam is used to assess for intra-abdominal bleeding. This patient has no abdominal tenderness or hemodynamic instability to suggest such an injury. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.
❌ X-rays of upper and lower extremities:
Incorrect: There is no reported pain, deformity, swelling, or bruising in the upper or lower extremities to suggest the need for imaging. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Abdominal CT is not indicated in a stable patient without signs of abdominal trauma such as tenderness, distention, or ecchymosis. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.

questions.text: A newborn boy is born at 39 weeks of gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Vacuum extraction is necessary. Apgars are 6 and 9. The pregnancy was complicated by diet-controlled diabetes mellitus in the mother. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 152/min, respirations are 42/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Birth weight is 4100 grams. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. The infant is crying vigorously with eyes closed. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. Which of the following birth-related head injuries, if found on exam, could be diagnosed clinically without the need for imaging?

choices.text: Discrete area of swelling on the scalp that does not cross suture lines
Swelling over the skull with palpable crepitus
Palpable skull concavity with bleeding from the nose and seizure activity
Fluctuating boggy scalp edema with a fluid wave that crosses suture lines

questions.solution:
This infant is born via vaginal delivery via the use of vacuum forceps. The pregnancy was complicated by diet-controlled diabetes mellitus in the mother and a newborn who is large for gestational age. Discrete swelling on the scalp that does not cross suture lines is indicative of a cephalohematoma, which is caused by bleeding under the scalp. Cephalohematomas can be diagnosed clinically without the need for imaging.        

Newborns with head injuries from birth trauma can be stable or unstable with altered level of consciousness or seizures. Unstable patients should be evaluated for subgaleal or intracranial hemorrhages with head ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain. They should have continuous vital sign monitoring and serial hemoglobin and hematocrits to monitor for anemia.        

Although infants with suspected skull fractures may not be critically ill, they also require a CT scan of the brain. Patients presenting with cephalohematomas or caput succedaneums will typically be stable. Further imaging is not necessary with suspected cephalohematomas as they typically resolve on their own.       

Newborns with traumatic deliveries should also be examined for the presence of focal nerve deficits. Patients with facial nerve palsy present with decreased movement on one side of the face, and patients with brachial plexus palsy present with deformity and limited range of movement of one arm. Newborns with traumatic delivery should also be assessed for musculoskeletal injuries, such as clavicular or long bone fractures, as well as soft tissue injuries. If there is concern for a fracture, radiographs should be performed. 

Option Analysis

✅ Discrete area of swelling on the scalp that does not cross suture lines:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Swelling over the skull with palpable crepitus :
Incorrect: Swelling over the skull with palpable crepitus is consistent with a linear skull fracture that would require further imaging. Swelling of the scalp that does not cross suture lines is consistent with a cephalohematoma, which does not require further work-up. 
❌ Palpable skull concavity with bleeding from the nose and seizure activity:
Incorrect: These findings would indicate a depressed skull fracture with intracranial hemorrhage, which should be urgently evaluated with imaging. 
❌ Palpable skull concavity:
Incorrect: A palpable skull concavity suggests a depressed skull fracture with possible associated intracranial hemorrhage. This requires additional imaging, unlike a cephalohematoma. 
❌ Fluctuating boggy scalp edema with a fluid wave that crosses suture lines:
Incorrect: Fluctuating scalp edema with a fluid wave across suture lines can be seen with a subgaleal hemorrhage, which requires further imaging. In contrast, focal swelling of the scalp that does not cross suture lines is consistent with a cephalohematoma, which does not require further work-up.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling two stories while washing windows on scaffolding. Per paramedics, the patient fell directly on his back, was helmeted, and did not suffer the loss of consciousness. On arrival, temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 178/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient’s primary survey is intact. The patient's secondary survey is notable for bruising and tenderness over the cervical and thoracic spine. A neurological examination demonstrates loss of sensation starting below the xiphoid process. The patient has 2+ triceps and brachioradialis reflexes and 5/5 strength of the upper extremities bilaterally. The patient is unable to move the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following reflects the most likely level of spinal injury?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for trauma evaluation after sustaining an injury to the spine. The neurologic examination is consistent with preserved sensation and motor strength above the level of T7, which is best approximated at the xiphoid process level.    

Pathologies that affect the spinal cord are diverse and include trauma, ischemia, infection, autoimmune conditions, neoplasm, and hereditary-degenerative diseases. Compressive etiologies (e.g. those resulting in direct physical impingement on the spinal cord) include tumors, spinal epidural abscesses, hematomas, herniated disks, or bony disease. Spinal cord transection can also result from direct trauma such as stab wounds, gunshot wounds, or extreme shearing forces. Ischemia, particularly from the anterior or posterior spinal arteries, may also result in injury to the spinal cord.    

Regardless of the etiology, the level of injury can be determined via a focused neurological assessment, including sensation testing, motor function testing, and reflex testing. The absence of sensation below a particular dermatome in conjunction with correlating motor and reflex deficits can indicate the level of a lesion.  


Option Analysis

✅ T7:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ T4:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at T4 would present with loss of sensation below the nipple line; this patient has preserved sensation at this dermatome.  
❌ C2:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at C2 would result in loss of sensation below the posterior half of the skull; injuries to this spinal level are often lethal due to damage to brainstem structures.  
❌ C4:
Incorrect: Injury to the C4 level would result in loss of sensation below the collar line and possible diaphragmatic dysfunction since this spinal cord level helps innervate the diaphragm.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: A spinal cord lesion at T10 would result in loss of sensation starting at the level of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to a primary care clinic by his partner for evaluation of ongoing behavioral problems. The patient has a long history of aggressive behavioral outbursts and is known to be apathetic and unapologetic for his actions. Past medical history includes blunt head trauma at age 22 after being struck in the head with an iron rod. Prior to the accident, the patient was well-mannered and an excellent student; however, after the accident, he became progressively distractible, disobedient towards adults of authority, and quarrelsome. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Damage to which of the following cortical areas is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s behavioral changes?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits abnormal behavior including aggression, distractibility, apathy, and impulsivity. These changes in behavior are reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.  

The prefrontal cortex is located anterior to the precentral area in the frontal lobe and includes the superior, middle, and inferior frontal gyri. It harbors both afferent and efferent pathways to and from the thalamus, hypothalamus, cerebral cortex, and the corpus striatum. The prefrontal cortex governs personality, social behavior, and executive functions, including decision making, reasoning, and emotional regulation.  

Damage to the prefrontal cortex results in disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior. Re-emergence of primitive reflexes are often observed.

Damage to the prefrontal cortex can occur secondary to trauma, cerebrovascular disease, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease (e.g. fronto-temporal dementia).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Prefrontal cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Broca’s area:
Incorrect: Broca’s area lies at the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere and has connections to the motor cortex – specifically to areas that control the muscles of the larynx, mouth, soft palate, and the tongue, as well as muscles of respiration. The primary function of this area includes formation, or production, of words and speech. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Wernicke’s area:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area encompasses a portion of the superior temporal gyrus along with the supramarginal and angular gyri of the parietal lobe. This area of the brain is responsible for comprehending written and spoken language. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Rostral to the premotor cortex and extending into the middle frontal gyrus is the frontal eye field, which controls voluntary eye movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity and integrates both sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by his partner after being found unresponsive one hour ago. The patient fell down a flight of stairs the previous evening, but he appeared fine immediately afterwards, and he went to bed at his usual time. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/102 mm Hg. On examination, the right pupil is 5 mm and fixed. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light. There is an extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination demonstrates a systolic click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is started. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows a right-sided 6-cm subdural hematoma with an 18-mm midline shift and associated cerebral edema. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Right eye esotropia and upward deviation

questions.solution:
This patient has a large right-sided subdural hematoma, resulting in elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral edema, presenting as midline shift and transtentorial herniation of the uncus.

With this type of herniation, the uncus (the innermost portion of the temporal lobe) slips down towards the tentorium and compresses parts of the brain stem. The following neurologic deficits are commonly observed with transtentorial herniation of the uncus:

  •  CN III nerve palsy, where the eye is fixed in a “down and out” position with a dilated and unresponsive pupil. 
  •  Posterior cerebral artery compression leads to contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.  
  •  Paramedian basilar artery injury results in small linear or flame-shaped hemorrhages called Duret hemorrhages. 
  •  Contralateral hemiparesis is secondary to compression of the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle of the midbrain, damaging corticospinal fibers. 
  •  Contralateral peduncle compression against the tentorium results in ipsilateral hemiparesis, known as a false localizing sign, the so-called Kernohan's notch. 

Option Analysis

❌ Right eye esotropia and upward deviation  :
Incorrect: Right eye esotropia and elevation would be caused by concomitant CN IV and VI palsies, leading to unopposed CN III activity. When CN III is unopposed, the associated extraocular muscles produce adduction and elevation or depression of the eye. Instead, uncal herniation causes CN III palsy, resulting in pupillary dilation and absent light reflex (as seen in this patient), abduction, and slight depression of the eye (“down and out” gaze).  
❌ Multifocal myoclonus  :
Incorrect: Multifocal myoclonus is associated with various neurologic disorders, including seizures. It is more frequently observed in severe cerebral hypoxia, progressive myoclonic epilepsy, neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer disease), or metabolic coma (e.g. secondary to glycemic disturbances). However, it is not a common symptom of uncal herniation.  
❌ Left-side vagus nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) exits the brainstem via the medulla, which lies at a position too inferior to be affected by uncal herniation. CN X can be injured via direct trauma to the neck and can also occur due to compression from an aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Bilateral vestibulocochlear nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII can be injured by hemorrhage or aneurysms of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  
✅ Right-sided hemiplegia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the back. The patient was the victim of a robbery and was shot while attempting to flee the scene. Temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the patient's secondary survey is notable for a single gunshot wound at the T10 spinal level without an exit wound. An emergent MRI demonstrates complete transection of the spinal cord at the level of T10.  Which of the following neurologic deficits are most likely to be expected based on this patient's spinal cord injury?

choices.text: Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation after sustaining a gunshot wound that results in a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T10. At this level, neurologic deficits to be expected would be a total loss of sensation at the level of the umbilicus and loss of motor function of the bilateral lower extremities.   

The spinal cord is divided into several different cross-sectional anatomic tracts and levels based on the corresponding vertebrae; an injury at any one of these levels or within the anatomic tract results in distinct neurologic deficits. During a spinal cord transection, the patient loses all sensation and voluntary movement inferior to the lesion site. For example, if a transaction occurs between C4 and C5, the patient will lose all motor and sensory functions below this level, rendering them quadriplegic.  If transection happens between C6 and C8, there’s a complete loss of lower limb function combined with a loss of hand and a variable amount of upper limb function.  

Damage to specific tracts can also occur via partial spinal cord transection. For example, Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that arises following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to damage to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure).  



Option Analysis

✅ Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T7, not T10.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C5. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C3. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only  :
Incorrect: This choice is not a physically realistic possibility. Complete loss of sensation at the neckline without the involvement of lower extremity weakness would not occur.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate acute-on-chronic low back pain. Several years ago, the patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer, but he elected to forego treatment and was lost to follow-up. Today, the patient was brought in by family members after he could not get out of bed. The patient states, “I can’t lift my legs, and I woke up covered in my stool.” The patient has no other significant medical history or medication use. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows a cachectic male in moderate distress. The patient has diffuse lumbar spinal tenderness to palpation and 2/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally. The patient’s pelvic x-ray is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features most indicates this patient’s clinical condition?


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of prostate cancer presents for evaluation of acute-on-chronic low back pain with associated bowel dysfunction, motor deficits in the lower extremities, and a pelvic x-ray demonstrating numerous osteoblastic lesions consistent with metastatic disease. This clinical presentation is suspicious for cauda equina syndrome, and urinary retention is a particularly specific finding for this condition.    
Cauda equina syndrome refers to a spinal cord injury caudal to the conus that injures two or more nerve roots, often via direct compression of the cauda equina within the lumbar spinal canal. The disease has multiple etiologies, including ankylosing spondylitis, chemotherapy, disc herniation, osteomyelitis, spinal epidural abscess, neoplasm, hematoma, arteriovenous malformations, inferior vena cava thrombosis, or trauma.  

The most common presenting complaint is acute-on-chronic low back pain; however, the associated features vary. In general, most patients have a combination of back pain, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and symptoms of radiculopathy. Additional findings include lower extremity weakness and diminished sensation in the distribution of multiple nerve roots (L3-S1), peri-anal numbness, and loss of anal sphincter tone. This disorder, while rare, carries significant morbidity, often resulting in permanent neurologic dysfunction if left untreated. When suspected, management includes emergent MRI of the lumbar spine and neurosurgical consultation.



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: The absence of deep tendon reflexes is often found in patients with cauda equina syndrome; however, it is not a specific feature of this condition as it may be found in simple, unilateral radiculopathy as well.  
❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: Hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia, is more commonly found in patients with cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Preserved perineal sensation :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome usually exhibits sensory loss in the perineal area (saddle anesthesia).  
❌ Increased anal sphincter tone :
Incorrect: Decreased, not increased, anal sphincter tone is observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent sciatica symptoms. The patient has had low back pain that radiates down the back of his left leg for weeks after he fell while skiing. The patient states, “The symptoms are getting so bad that I feel the leg is getting weaker. I’ve tried physical therapy, but it does not work.” The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has 4/5 strength with plantar flexion and a 1+ ankle jerk reflex on physical examination of the left leg. The right leg has 5/5 strength and full reflexes. Which of the following myotomes is most likely affected based on this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of persistent sciatica and has evidence of S1 radiculopathy given this patient’s clinical findings of pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion and diminished ankle jerk reflex.   

Deep tendon reflexes can provide valuable information regarding the level of spinal cord involvement or damage to a particular nerve route. When this reflex is triggered, stretch receptors in the muscle-tendon send afferent impulses to the spinal cord through their cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion, which then synapse with alpha motor neurons. Alpha motor neurons then transmit an automatic efferent signal back to the muscle leading to a contraction.    

Critical deep tendon reflexes include the brachioradialis and biceps tendon, which test myotome C5 and C6; the triceps tendon, which tests C6, C7, and C8; the patellar tendon, which tests L2, L3, and L4; and the Achilles tendon, which tests S1 and S2. Hyperactive reflexes indicate an upper motor neuron problem within the spinal cord or central nervous system, whereas hypoactive reflexes indicate peripheral nerve pathology.  


Option Analysis

✅ S1-S2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 is the myotome reflecting the knee jerk reflex, which is elicited by tapping on the patellar tendon while the knee flexes.  
❌ S3-S4:
Incorrect: S3-S4 is the myotome reflecting the anal wink reflex. This reflex may be absent in cauda equina syndrome due to compression of these nerve roots.  
❌ L1-L2:
Incorrect: L1-L2 are the myotomes associated with the cremasteric reflex, which will often be diminished in cases of testicular torsion.  
❌ C5-C6:
Incorrect: The C5-C6 myotome is associated with the biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, which are not implicated in this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department as a level 1 trauma following a fall from scaffolding. The patient worked as a painter and slipped and fell approximately 20 ft, landing on his back. Upon arrival, the patient has a GCS of 15 and endorses pain in his lower back. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and his secondary survey is notable for a step-off and pain at the T12-L1 spinal level. An emergent MRI of the spine is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features is most specific to this patient's clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation following back trauma and has an MRI that demonstrates a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body with subsequent compression on the conus medullaris. This neurosurgical emergency presents with all the clinical features of cauda equina syndrome, plus upper motor neuron deficits such as hyperreflexia.    

Conus medullaris syndrome is a rare neurosurgical emergency that refers to compression of the conus medullaris from trauma, spinal epidural abscess, hematoma, or disc herniation. This pathologic entity presents with many overlapping features of cauda equina syndrome, including acute lower back pain with associated lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction.  

Key differentiating features of conus medullaris syndrome include the presence of upper motor neuron deficits (e.g. hyperreflexia, increased tone) and symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness. The latter may be mild if the lesion is restricted and spares both the lumbar cord and the adjacent sacral and lumbar nerve roots. In addition, conus medullaris syndrome is more commonly implicated in spinal lesions from T12-L1 since the spinal cord terminates as the conus medullaris at this level in most adult patients. Trauma or lesions below this spinal level are unlikely to result in conus medullaris syndrome.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Saddle anesthesia :
Incorrect: Saddle anesthesia is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific.  
❌ Asymmetric lower extremity weakness:
Incorrect: Symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness is more likely to be found in patients with conus medullaris syndrome; however, it can also be observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome and is therefore nonspecific.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Urinary retention is found in both conditions and is not specific to conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Decreased bulbocavernosus reflex:
Incorrect: A decreased bulbocavernosus reflex is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific to either condition.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department after being involved in a street fight. The patient was punched in the left eye and subsequently developed eye pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), the pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows a laceration on the left brow, left-sided periorbital ecchymosis, and subconjunctival hemorrhage. The left eye appears slightly sunken compared to the right. The visual acuity is as expected in both eyes on the Snellen chart. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown.


Reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient received a direct blow to the orbit during a street fight that resulted in an orbital floor fracture. The CT scan demonstrates herniation of the inferior rectus muscle into the maxillary sinus, which can cause impairment of upward gaze.  

The orbital floor is composed of a thin layer of bone that separates the orbit from the air-filled maxillary sinus. Orbital floor fractures, sometimes known as "blowout fractures,” result from force transmitted from blunt trauma (e.g., when a small, round object such as a baseball or fist strikes the eye) through the orbital soft tissue into the bony orbital walls. This commonly results in fractures of the medial and inferior orbital walls due to the thin bone in these areas.    

Since the inferior rectus muscle lies directly above the orbital floor, it can herniate through a fracture in the floor of the orbit and into the maxillary sinus below. If the muscle becomes entrapped in the fracture, the patient will demonstrate limited upward gaze and thus vertical diplopia. Injury to the infraorbital nerve (resulting in decreased sensation along the cheek, upper lip, or upper gingiva) may also occur due to an orbital floor fracture.  

Fracture is usually evident on radiographic imaging, and fluids or herniation of orbital contents can be visualized in the adjacent, normally air-filled sinuses or nasal cavities.   

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired upward gaze:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Absent corneal reflex:
Incorrect: Corneal reflex can be impaired with orbital fissure fractures, as the nerves involved (CNV1 and CN VII) pass through it. It is not affected by orbital floor fractures. 
❌ Bruising of the mastoid process:
Incorrect: Bruising of the mastoid process and periorbital ecchymosis and clear otorrhea suggest basal skull fracture. 
❌ Fixed and dilated left pupil:
Incorrect: A fixed and dilated left pupil can occur in the setting of orbital trauma due to increased intraorbital pressure. This can occur from retrobulbar hematoma or other causes of orbital compartment syndrome. This would be accompanied by proptosis, which is not found in this patient. 
❌ Impaired olfaction:
Incorrect: Nasal fractures or high force trauma to the midface can impair olfaction if olfactory nerves are torn from the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. This patient has an orbital floor fracture.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient is unresponsive, and the paramedics report a witnessed generalized-tonic-clonic seizure. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. On examination, the patient appears comatose with mispositioned and fixed pupils. The upper extremities are adducted, extended, and in hyperpronation.
