The lower extremities appear extended, adducted, and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. A non-contrast CT scan of the head demonstrates extensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage with a horizontal shift of midline structures. Damage to which of the following anatomic structures most likely contributed to the extensor posturing observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage that is complicated by brain herniation (coma, mispositioned and fixed pupils, and rigid extension of upper and lower extremities).

Abnormal posturing secondary to brain herniation results from disruption of the descending tracts (e.g. rubrospinal and vestibulospinal tracts) involved in reflexive and postural movements. The red nucleus in the midbrain gives rise to the rubrospinal tract, which acts on the proximal flexor musculature of the upper limbs.  
 
  •  Transection or injury to the brainstem at the level of the red nucleus or below the red nucleus (pons) damages the rubrospinal tract. Spared vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts overstimulate extensor muscles, leading to the characteristic decerebrate/extensor posturing where the upper extremities are adducted, extended and in hyperpronation, while the lower extremities are also extended, adducted and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. 
 
  •  Damage above the level of the red nucleus (e.g. cerebral hemisphere and internal capsule) over stimulates the flexor muscles of the upper extremities. The unaffected vestibulospinal and pontine reticulospinal tracts stimulate the extensor muscles of the body leading to decorticate/flexion posturing, where upper extremities are adducted and flexed with wrists, hands and fingers flexed into fists near the chest, while the lower extremities remain extended and internally rotated with feet in plantarflexion and big toes pointing medially. 


Option Analysis

❌ Locus coeruleus  :
Incorrect:  The locus coeruleus houses norepinephrine secreting neurons that participate in fight and flight responses during physical and emotional stress. It is located in the dorsal pons and does not affect the motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
✅ Red nucleus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raphe nuclei  :
Incorrect: The raphe nuclei are located in the midbrain, pons, and medulla and project widely through the CNS. They house serotonergic neurons which play a role in sleep-wake cycle, anxiety, psychosis and mood changes. They do not affect motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
❌ Substantia nigra:
Incorrect: The substantia nigra contains dopaminergic neurons, which are depleted in Parkinson disease. This disease presents with bradykinesia, involuntary tremor, and rigidity.  
❌ Nucleus basalis of Meynert  :
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis of Meynert houses the cell bodies of cholinergic neurons. Decreased acetylcholine is released from these neurons in patients with Alzheimer disease.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman is in the emergency department following a skateboarding accident. The patient was jumping down a flight of stairs when she lost control and fell onto concrete without wearing a helmet. She had a brief loss of consciousness following the accident. The patient reports nausea,  headache and has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. Her past medical history is insignificant, and she does not take any medications. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time on physical examination. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia, but no abnormal heart sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise in the left temporal region. A non-contrast head CT is shown.


Reproduced from Radiopedia

 Rupture of which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of head trauma, loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval, and subsequent signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache and vomiting). The non-contrast head CT demonstrates an epidural hematoma, likely from a middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery) hemorrhage.  

Epidural hematoma commonly results from a blow to the side of the head, resulting in the fracture of the thin bones that form the pterion (junction of the greater wing of sphenoid, squamous temporal, frontal, and parietal bones). The pterion overlies the course of the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery, and fractures in the region may injure the artery, causing epidural hemorrhage.



Patients with epidural hematoma typically manifest with a lucid interval after an initial loss of consciousness, followed by signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, decreased mental status, anisocoria, and Cushing reflex). Epidural hematomas are diagnosed with non-contrast CT scans and demonstrate biconvex, hyperdense masses confined to the suture lines between the dura mater and the skull. 

Option Analysis

❌ Cortical bridging veins :
Incorrect: Rupture of cortical bridging veins can result in subdural hemorrhage. In young patients, this occurs usually as the result of a fall or motor vehicle accident. The onset of symptoms is usually gradual, with a slow decline in mental function. A subdural hemorrhage is visualized as a crescent-shaped mass on a CT scan.  
❌ Berry aneurysm:
Incorrect: The anterior communicating artery is the most common site of a berry aneurysm. Its rupture can result in subarachnoid hemorrhage, which usually manifests as a sudden, severe headache, described as the “worst headache of my life.”  
❌ Posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: The posterior communicating artery is the second most common location for berry aneurysms. Its rupture can result in subarachnoid hemorrhage, which usually manifests as a sudden, severe headache, described as the “worst headache of my life.” 
✅ Middle meningeal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Lateral striate artery:
Incorrect: Lateral striate arteries arise from middle cerebral arteries. These vessels supply the internal capsule and basal ganglia and often rupture in hypertensive strokes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was unresponsive and subsequently had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during transport. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, and cocaine misuse. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg. The patient is comatose with downward, fixed pupils and rigid extension of the upper and lower extremities bilaterally on physical examination. A cross-sectional CT scan demonstrates complete obliteration of the perimesencephalic and premedullary cisterns and a truncated brainstem with Duret hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a traumatic brain injury and intraparenchymal hemorrhage progressing to brain herniation. Mass effect from intracranial hemorrhage can raise the intracranial pressure (ICP), ultimately leading to the physiologic effects of hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea (Cushing triad). With hemorrhage expansion, central/downward brain herniation may occur.

In central herniation, the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes of both cerebral hemispheres herniate through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. As the brainstem becomes inferiorly displaced, damage to the midbrain and upper pons results in mid-positioned and fixed pupils due to loss of sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation. In addition, paralysis of upward eye movement occurs, leading to the sunset eyes sign (eyes appear driven downward). Duret hemorrhages (due to the rupture of paramedian basilar artery branches) can be seen in central herniation. Brain herniation also results in abnormal posturing due to the disruption of the descending tract typically involved in reflexive and postural movements (which accounts for the decerebrate posturing seen in this patient).  

Option Analysis

❌ Subfalcine herniation:
Incorrect: Subfalcine herniation occurs when the innermost portion of the frontal lobe herniates under a portion of the falx cerebri. This injury does not put as much pressure on the brainstem as the other types of herniation but does compress the anterior cerebral artery manifesting in dysarthria and leg weakness. This patient’s presentation is instead suggestive of central/downward herniation.  
✅ Downward transtentorial herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upward herniation  :
Incorrect: Increased pressure in the posterior fossa can cause the cerebellum to move up through the tentorial opening and push the midbrain through the tentorial notch. Patients typically present with nausea and vomiting with rapid progression to a depressed level of consciousness and death. This patient’s presentation suggests central/downward herniation secondary to increased intracranial pressure.  
❌ Cerebellar tonsillar herniation  :
Incorrect: In tonsillar herniation, the cerebellar tonsils move downward through the foramen magnum, causing compression of the lower brainstem and upper cervical spinal cord. Decerebrate posturing is not observed with this lesion. The most common signs include intractable headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness due to tonsillar impaction.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation:
Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or opening in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of altered mental status. He was working on a construction site when he fell approximately 15 feet from a ladder, landing on his back. His coworkers found him unresponsive and immediately called 9-1-1. Emergency medical services arrived soon after. Glascow coma scale score was 7, and he was intubated in the field. He has no known past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 156/66 mmHg. On examination, he does not open his eyes, nor does he spontaneously move, he does withdraw to pain. Abrasions are noted on the occiput. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 34-year-old patient presents with head trauma. He has signs and symptoms suggesting an unstable subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) including inability to protect his airway, altered breathing, and abnormal circulation following a significant traumatic head injury. The first steps in the management of unstable SAH are to stabilize the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation and to assess for signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). If increased ICP is present, management includes elevating the head of the bed, hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.       

The initial stabilization of a patient presenting with SAH may include intubation and mechanical ventilation. Intravenous access should be secured along with continuous vital sign monitoring, including cardiac telemetry. Patients should be monitored for signs of the physiological response to increased ICP known as the Cushing triad, which consists of the triad of bradycardia, hypertension/widened pulse pressure, and decreased respirations/irregular respirations.        

If patients have findings consistent with increased ICP, then an ICP monitor should be placed, and medical management should be initiated immediately. Patients should be monitored for any changes in status. Physical examination may reveal fixed and dilated pupils in the case of impending herniation. If increased ICP persists despite medical management, cerebrospinal fluid diversion may be considered. If these fail to reduce intracranial pressure, then, an emergent decompressive craniectomy may be needed.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperventilation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 0.9% intravenous (IV) saline:
Incorrect: This patient with head trauma has Cushing Triad which indicates increased intracranial pressure (ICP). He should be treated with intubation and mechanical ventilation, and hyperventilation, in addition to sedation, elevation of the head of the bed, and hyperosmolar therapy with either hypertonic fluids, as opposed to normal saline, or mannitol. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) epinephrine:
Incorrect: While epinephrine can be used for patients with bradycardia from different causes, this patient presents with recent head trauma and Cushing triad, consisting of bradycardia, hypertension with widened pulse pressure, and decreased and irregular respirations secondary to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). ICP can be exacerbated by administration of epinephrine. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) labetalol:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs of the Cushing triad, including bradycardia, hypertension with widened pulse pressure, and decreased and irregular respirations, suggestive of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Hypertension should be treated in the case of a subarachnoid hemorrhage when the systolic pressure exceeds 160 mmHg. 
❌ Trendelenburg position:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of increased intracranial pressure, (ICP), which is treated by elevating the head of the bed (i.e., reverse Trendelenburg position), rather than lowering it in the Trendelenburg position, along with hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old individual is reevaluated in the intensive care unit for ongoing management following cardiopulmonary arrest after being found unresponsive in an apartment 48 hours ago. Past medical history is unknown. A urine drug screen on arrival to the emergency department is negative. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min by mechanical ventilation, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. The patient is intubated and not receiving intravenous sedation. The patient remains unconscious without localizing movements in response to painful stimuli. There are intermittent arm flexion and arm-crossing movements. Brainstem reflexes are absent. Deep tendon reflexes are present bilaterally. Computed tomography (CT) of the head shows loss of gray-white matter differentiation. Current laboratory values are shown below. The treating physician is planning to perform apnea testing. Which of the following findings prohibits the physician from confirming the suspected diagnosis at this time?

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 113 mEq/L
 Potassium 3.4 mEq/L
 Chloride 95 mEq/L
 Creatinine 1.9 mg/dL
 Albumin 3.2 g/dL
 BUN/Cr > 20
 Toxicology
 Serum ethanol 0 mg/dL
 Acetaminophen level 5 mcg/mL
questions.solution:
This patient’s treating physician is planning to perform an apnea test, which is used to help confirm a diagnosis of brain death. However, the patient’s markedly low sodium level (hyponatremia) prohibits the confirmation of this diagnosis and must be corrected before further testing can proceed.

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain function and may result from trauma, stroke, hypoxic-ischemic injury, mass lesions, infections, or toxic/metabolic disturbances. Neuroimaging often demonstrates cerebral edema, typically evidenced by loss of gray-white matter differentiation, and may reveal signs of herniation.

Before brain death can be confirmed, other potential causes of the patient’s clinical state must be excluded. This includes observing the patient for a sufficient period, typically at least 24 hours, to assess for any signs of neurologic improvement. Medications that could affect consciousness or the neurologic examination, such as barbiturates or benzodiazepines, must be ruled out or metabolized. Laboratory evaluation should assess for correctable metabolic or acid-base disturbances. The patient must not be under the effects of neuromuscular blockade. In addition, prerequisites for testing include a core body temperature of at least 36°C, a systolic blood pressure of 100 mm Hg or higher, and a mean arterial pressure of at least 75 mm Hg.

Option Analysis

✅ Sodium level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: Spinally mediated reflexes such as deep tendon reflexes may persist in brain death and do not exclude the diagnosis.
❌ Intermittent arm crossing movements:
Incorrect: These movements are consistent with spinal automatism (i.e. Lazarus sign), which can occur in brain death and do not preclude the diagnosis.
❌ Acetaminophen level:
Incorrect: An acetaminophen level of 5 mcg/mL is not clinically significant and unlikely to contribute to the patient’s presentation.
❌ Potassium level:
Incorrect: A potassium level of 3.4 mEq/L is mildly low but not severe enough to account for this patient's neurological status.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department following an altercation in which another individual stabbed the patient on the right side of the neck with a screwdriver. Witnesses report that the patient collapsed at the scene. There is no known medical history, and no medications are taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg. On examination, the patient is alert and appears appropriately anxious. The screwdriver is lodged in the right posterior neck. There is flaccid paralysis of the right arm and leg, along with impaired proprioception and vibration sense on the right. There are spontaneous movements of the left arm and leg. Which of the following additional examination findings confirms the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left arm and leg

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of hemicord syndrome, as evidenced by unilateral weakness and sensory deficits following penetrating spinal cord trauma. In this condition, damage to the dorsal column on the affected side results in ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception since these fibers ascend ipsilaterally before decussating in the medulla. Additionally, involvement of the contralateral spinothalamic tract leads to loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side, as these fibers cross near their level of entry in the spinal cord.        

The differential diagnosis for a suspected spinal cord lesion in adults depends in part on the level of involvement. When weakness or sensory loss is absent in the cervical or thoracic regions, conditions such as conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome should be considered. When present, the differential is broader and includes central cord syndrome; anterior, posterior, hemicord, or complete cord syndromes; syringomyelia; spinal cord infarction; subacute combined degeneration; tabes dorsalis, penetrating trauma; spinal cord compression; cord transection; and transverse myelitis. The pattern of sensory loss, along with the presence, absence, and distribution of weakness, helps to narrow the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left arm and leg:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rightward tongue deviation:
Incorrect: Tongue deviation suggests cranial nerve XII involvement, which is not expected with a cervical hemicord lesion. 
❌ Right pupillary dilation:
Incorrect: Right pupillary dilation would indicate unopposed sympathetic activity or impaired parasympathetic input, typically resulting from brainstem or cranial nerve III involvement. A cervical hemicord lesion affects spinal cord tracts, not the midbrain or oculomotor pathways. 
❌ Left hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: This patient has a cervical hemicord lesion. Hyperreflexia would be expected on the same side as the lesion (right), due to involvement of the ipsilateral corticospinal tract. 
❌ Dysarthria:
Incorrect: Dysarthria is more consistent with cortical or brainstem involvement, not an isolated spinal cord injury.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by ambulance after being found unresponsive in the lake behind his home. The patient’s partner reports that the patient had gone outside to watch the sunset after consuming several cocktails. The partner later discovered the patient in the water, limp and unresponsive. Emergency personnel initiated cardiopulmonary resuscitation and return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) was achieved after 15 minutes. On arrival to the ED, the patient is comatose. A laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in place, and a 16-gauge peripheral IV has been established. Temperature is 35.5°C (95.9°F), blood pressure 94/50 mmHg, heart rate is 54/min, respiratory rate is 14/min (via LMA), and oxygen saturation is 95% on 100% FiO₂ via bag-valve mask. The patient does not respond to verbal commands or noxious stimulation. Pupils are 3 mm and nonreactive to light. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with possible hypoxic-ischemic brain injury following a possible drowning incident. Clinical findings supporting this include unresponsiveness, absence of purposeful motor responses to stimuli, and nonreactive pupils, suggesting loss of brainstem reflexes. The most appropriate next step is to provide definitive airway and respiratory support through intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain activity, including consciousness, brainstem reflexes, and spontaneous respiratory effort. It can result from a variety of causes such as trauma, stroke, hypoxic-ischemic injury, mass effect from structural lesions, infections, or toxic-metabolic disturbances. Most patients with brain death or impending brain death present with coma and should be considered medically unstable.

Until brain death is formally confirmed, and in the absence of legal documentation limiting resuscitative efforts, aggressive stabilization measures should be initiated, including those aimed at supporting the airway, breathing, and circulation. In most cases, intubation and mechanical ventilation are required to secure the airway and maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. Intravenous access should be established, and the patient should be placed on continuous monitoring of vital signs.

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Active rewarming:
Incorrect: Although the patient is mildly hypothermic, rewarming is not the immediate priority. Airway management and ventilation take precedence, especially in a comatose patient who is not breathing spontaneously.
❌ Continuous infusion of norepinephrine:
Incorrect: While this patient is hypotensive, the mean arterial pressure is currently 65 mmHg, so vasopressor therapy is not the first priority. Intubation and mechanical ventilation should be initiated first to stabilize oxygenation and ventilation. Vital signs should be monitored closely with initiation of circulatory support if hypotension worsens.
❌ Intravenous levetiracetam:
Incorrect: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic commonly used for seizure prophylaxis in patients with traumatic brain injury or hypoxic-ischemic brain injury. However, in this case, the patient requires definitive airway management to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: Although the patient may have suffered hypoxic-ischemic brain injury or trauma, imaging should be deferred until the airway is secured and the patient is stabilized. A CT scan is not the immediate next step in management.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is hospitalized in the intensive care unit for 72 hours following a cardiopulmonary arrest. The patient is intubated and off sedation but remains unconscious without motor response to stimuli. Brainstem reflexes are absent. Serum toxicology is negative, and there are no metabolic or acid-base derangements. Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, treated with lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 12/min (ventilator set rate), and blood pressure is 155/85 mmHg. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain obtained yesterday showed loss of gray-white matter differentiation, and a computed tomography (CT) scan today demonstrates signs of herniation. During apnea testing, there is no respiratory effort, and arterial PaCO₂ rises from 38 mmHg to 68 mmHg. Which of the following should be considered part of an evidence-based approach to treating this patient?

choices.text: Notify the family, provide counseling and support, and notify the organ donation organization
Notify the family after you have evaluated the patient for organ transplantation candidacy
Discontinue mechanical and pharmacological support while allowing the family to decide about organ transplantation
Perform 4-vessel catheter angiography to confirm the diagnosis
Radionucleotide perfusion imaging to confirm the diagnosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s examination findings, imaging, and positive apnea test confirm brain death. The time of death should be documented, the family informed, counseling and support provided, and the appropriate organ donation organization notified.

If a patient meets all prerequisites for brain death determination, proceed with clinical evaluation, including the apnea test. A positive apnea test is indicated by the absence of spontaneous respirations and a rise in arterial carbon dioxide tension consistent with acidosis on serial blood gas measurements. Brain death can be declared at that time. Confirmatory testing to assess cerebral blood flow, such as four-vessel catheter angiography, radionuclide perfusion imaging, or transcranial Doppler ultrasonography, may be used when components of the clinical exam cannot be completed.

Clinicians involved in the patient's care must not participate in evaluating transplant eligibility, as doing so represents a conflict of interest. If organ donation is not pursued, families should be offered time with the deceased before mechanical and pharmacologic support is withdrawn.

Option Analysis

✅ Notify the family, provide counseling and support, and notify the organ donation organization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Notify the family after you have evaluated the patient for organ transplantation candidacy:
Incorrect: The family should be notified once brain death has been confirmed. The hospital team must notify the organ donation organization, which is responsible for evaluating transplant candidacy. Hospital staff should not delay family notification or assess candidacy themselves.
❌ Discontinue mechanical and pharmacological support while allowing the family to decide about organ transplantation:
Incorrect: Mechanical and pharmacological support should be continued to preserve organ viability while the organ donation organization conducts its evaluation. Withdrawal of support is appropriate only after donation is declined or the patient is deemed ineligible.
❌ Perform 4-vessel catheter angiography to confirm the diagnosis:
Incorrect: Catheter angiography is an ancillary test used only when elements of the clinical brain death exam cannot be completed or confounding factors exist. It is not needed when the full clinical assessment is adequate.
❌ Radionucleotide perfusion imaging to confirm the diagnosis:
Incorrect: Ancillary testing is not required when a comprehensive clinical evaluation, including apnea testing, confirms the diagnosis. Radionuclide studies are reserved for situations where the clinical exam is incomplete or inconclusive.
